June 28, 1962
Mr. E. G. Burrows
Chairman, NAEB Network Program Committee
WUOM
Ann Arbor, Michigan
Dear Ed:
Here are my comments concerning Harold Hill's memo dated June 14, 1962 concern¬
ing the suggestion of John Finster regarding a new quarterly system.
It appears to me that any arrangement of the quarters is arbitrary, as the offerings
based on quarters of the year. The three months between new offerings seems to be
quite adequate. Once a month offerings would involve too much work, and less fre¬
quent offerings, say every six months, would probably mean a large lag between the
initial offering to network, and the use by network stations.
If the three month interval is judged to be adequate, then the next decision is - what
three months? There is a certain convenience in the present system, primarily because
of the coincidence with the calendar. But I feel that this convenience is not enough
to outweigh the validity of Mr. Finster's suggestion, not only for school stations, but
also for those of us who prepare program guides with long advance deadlines. The
"Finster" plan would, in effect, present the offering one month prior to the convention¬
al quarter system, so that stations having this long deadline would end up having to
program in the conventional quarter, e.g.. Quarter IV (Sept.-Oct.-Nov. under the
"Finster" plan) would be broadcast on many stations in October, November and Decem¬
ber. Clear? - hope so.
To sum up, if the administrative details are not too great, I am in favor of the Finster
plan. It will present some problems as to the decision of which quarter will cover
only two months, but possibly this could be Summer of 1963.
Sincerely,
Harold W. Roeth
Program Manager
HWRrgwr
The non-commercial Metropolitan FM station of The Riverside Church in the City of New York
